title: When will hospitalizations for confirmed cases of COVID-19 in New York City (NYC) next reach or exceed 1,000 in a single day?
preds: Only 7 as of 15 September. Even the number of new infections has been under 1000 for four months now.
Increasing my very low probabilities a little bit, because I realize I'm not really that well calibrated for low percentages.
+1 to October 2020, time is almost out.

I joined Good Judgement after 1 Sep.  That eliminates the first three choices.  Given the option between before or after 1 October and the current daily hospitalization rate for the last week (oldest to newest: 63, 69, 61, 55, 77, 77, 73) there is little to now probability of the daily rate exceeding 1,000 before 1 October 2020.
https://www1.nyc.gov/site/doh/covid/covid-19-goals.page
+4 to not before October 1 based on passage of time and no signs of an increase in NYC.
NY has tamed covid and will continue to do so.
Stable under 50 for three months now, currently about 10. New York seems to almost have herd immunity / saturation.
13 on 8/30. Glad to see as one of my grand-daughters starts at NYU.

Non movement in new cases and hospitalizations. Immunity most likely at +25% of the population. See this as a less than 1/200 chance this will happen now, so changing to 100% not before 1 October. 1 Sep-30 Sep: -2
>1 Oct: +2
NYC has bent the curve so far

Gulp...College dorms are opening soon and people from out of state will be coming in. Sure testing before they get there but still a potential problem. Public schools pening may also ramp things up. 1000 is a low bar. Might get slammed.
The governor of New York state proves to be smart time and again, carefully cutting off all essential options for the virus in this public health mine field.

Hospitalizations are low and local state governments (NY/NJ/CT) have been proactive in opening services back up, even throttling down or holding back additional stages.  The wildcard is when students are in contact again indoors with some districts reopening 9/8, however the elderly took the brunt of the severe cases early on. If students are potentially infected around 9/8 and spread to family members, symptoms may not be realized until the last week of September with rates potentially rising at that point but not peaking until well past 10/1. Hospitalizations remain low in NYC and were last over 1,000 on 4/14. Distancing policies and PPE have helped, when used, to keep transmission rates low.  https://projects.thecity.nyc/2020_03_covid-19-tracker/
https://www1.nyc.gov/site/doh/covid/covid-19-data.page
Some immunity / social distancing still in place from big scare early on
Updating due to passed time and likelihood that they have decent herd immunity.
Right now they are in the 20's

This will be the start of the flu season which will complicate and exacerbate the next wave of the coronavirus.  Additionally this will be when we see the impact of kids returning to school with underfunded resources in the state resulting in high rates of infection and then hospitalizations.  This will cause rates to rise to this number or higher.
Hospitalizations are right now in the 20's.
Hospitalizations are right now in the 20's.

Hospitalization rates remain stable and low [1]. An acceleration to 1000 cases per day in Aug seems unlikely at this point, with a continued low chance in September. There are some concerning cases from parties, but they seem to be caught quickly before they can spread to far [2]. [1] https://www1.nyc.gov/site/doh/covid/covid-19-data.page
[2] https://www.nbcnewyork.com/news/local/dont-drop-your-guard-ny-nj-govs-warn-covid-progress-could-slide-and-in-some-ways-it-already-has/2541920/

Given the fact that New York seems to have weathered the initial wave of infections, and that New Yorkers are (for the most part) seemingly compliant with social distancing and mask policies, it is unlikely that hospitalizations will hit 1000 in a day again as long as things remain the same.  There is a rising trend of younger (21-30 y.o.) individuals becoming infected as they are generally less compliant with mask policies and assume they are less likely to become seriously ill, and this may continue to pose a problem; there has been a small spike in reported infections in the last few weeks due to parties held on July 4th.  However, these individuals would not be likely to cause daily hospitalizations to reach 1000 again.  The only concern is for the coming fall and winter, when flu season and cold weather will drive up infections; many scientists and epidemiologists believe a second wave would hit around this time.  However, those hospitalizations would also not be likely to occur until after October, which is beyond the scope of the question.
I don’t think it will happen until the weather cools significantly.

The paper "Projecting the transmission dynamics of SARS-CoV-2 through the postpandemic period" (https://science.sciencemag.org/content/368/6493/860) predicts a steep rise in R_eff starting early October for two related betacoronaviruses, CoV-HKU1 and CoV-OC43. Hospitalizations should lag the rise in R_eff by several days.
School's opening is the only unknown. Otheriwse New Yorkers are keeping this under control.
Note: there are increasing cases coming up from the South right up I-95 into NY so cases in NY increasing. Need to keep an eye in that.

Considering that NYC has managed to keep its daily hospitalization rate ultra low for some length of time, It is highly unlikely that they will increase that drastically so quickly.  The population there has a higher percentage of those displaying +Antibody testing (although I concede this is still not reliable as to immunity as early info shows decreasing levels of IgG by 50% in the first 36 days after infection - however the body is also using cell-mediated immunity as well to protect itself).  The fresh horror of hundreds around them being hospitalized and dying is also still fresh in their minds so they will be more likely to follow precautions.
Seems to be managing in a careful way. Out of towners in NYC might be a problem.

An important step that probably makes a second wave in NYC much less likely: "Amid concerns about a coronavirus resurgence, New York City will enter a limited fourth phase of reopening on Monday, allowing some art and entertainment venues, like zoos and botanical gardens, to open for outdoor activities at a limited capacity, officials announced on Friday ... But stringent restrictions will remain on indoor activities: Gyms, malls, movie theaters and museums will remain shuttered, and indoor dining will still not be allowed."  New hospitalizations are still low and have not exceeded 50 new daily admissions in over a month [2].  [1] https://www.nytimes.com/2020/07/17/nyregion/phase-4-nyc-reopen.html
[2] https://www1.nyc.gov/site/doh/covid/covid-19-data.page

NYC is currently hovering around 500 new cases a day as of July 15. The city is finally opening up a bit, meaning cases will rise back up soon. With a 2 week delay on the reopening and consumer confidence, plus a doubling every about week, I suspect the cases will rise above 1000 in about a month.

Parking here for now, but I still think the crowd us underweighting bin 4 in particular.  Folks are about to start going back to offices in NYC, and I don't much buy in to the part of my intuition that says "surely after the experience of April/May, they won't let it get out of hand again".

School holidays and being outside will keep things Low. There has been no uptick in hospitalisation yet at 10 jul.  But winter, school reopening may cause it to go up.  But given there are some treatments that seems to help and people are better learning when hospitalisation is really needed I think the numbers may nit get back to that level.  But who knows at the moment.  More likely to be later than sooner
Several weeks after kids are back in school and more employees are back at work.

Rates continue to drop for hospitalizations [1]. The state continues to take actions, overall, to reduce situations where the virus may spread, such as cancelling all county fairs [2]. While this doesn't impact NYC directly, it reduces the desire for people to travel and participate in group events. [1] https://www1.nyc.gov/site/doh/covid/covid-19-data.page
[2] https://www.syracuse.com/coronavirus/2020/07/coronavirus-in-ny-hospitalizations-up-slightly-all-county-fairs-canceled.html
New York numbers still holding in a good spot. R is still low, not many cases, low infection rate, etc.  https://public.tableau.com/profile/ckelly2528#!/vizhome/COVIDDashboard-Public/NationalOverview
I updated my prediction as it seems that virus load is much lower if citizens follow safety measures, even during reopening phase. In addition, NYC public schools will not fully reopen in September.

Updating my forecast on a few new bits of information. Lots of pressure to keep social distancing or threatening to take steps back is a concern and being expressed emotionally with micro gestures by Cuomo. A lot of people have left the city, to the Hamptons, and if NYC takes a step back the wealthy will stay away and stay online. Camps are closed. Its now a balancing act between the latest virus change which altered its crown to make it easier to attack humans and the summer heat and all that goes with it. If its hot, and people stay in with AC we create crowding and virus circulation via apartment ducts for the disease .
New York is moving in a good direction. Will revise forecast if that begins to change.
6th July: Number under 100 for last 32 days and the trend is decreasing
I am slow to catch on to new trends, sorry. It appears that NYC has figured out a model that lets them live with covid-19.
Updated numbers based on current trends - which continue to decline - and push back to control the spread
NY doing a good job so far. However, return to school may bring its own unique signature in September. June 1 saw 664 as the max so far this month.
NYC has the virus currently contained, it's unlikely to be opening up to a large degree soon until the lift issue is solved.

NYC is doing well but really just reopening. Given school opens in late August and early September would expect an uptick. It would mean those cases then would come to fruition in late September to early October. I will check the actual numbers with the link in a previous comment but will redo my percents.

Cases and hosptializations continue to drop [1]. With the national focus on the explosions of cases in TX, CA, and FL, [2] New Yorkers may be reminded of how bad they had it and stay with the basic hygiene, masks, and social distancing. [1] https://www1.nyc.gov/site/doh/covid/covid-19-data.page
[2] https://www.arcgis.com/apps/opsdashboard/index.html#/bda7594740fd40299423467b48e9ecf6

I am updating my forecast as I misread the question. I did not use the link provided in the explanation which would have made me realize this question was pertaining to new hospitalizations in a single day. I thought it was the total count of hospitalizations (new and existing) for a single day. Therefore, I am updating my forecast to reflect this change.

Hospitalization spike in Texas is quite humbling.  I don’t think we’ll see such steep growth in NYC, but then again, that wouldn’t even be necessary to hit the relatively low threshold here. Shifting some more weight to July/Aug/Sept.
Rate looks like it’s remaining stable.
Not seeing any up trend in the number of hospitalizations. Looks like NYC citizens have learnt their lessons well.

The peak for hospitalizations would need to see a significant rise of cases in July - current trends decreasing even if upticks showing - hospitalizations is a trailing indicator. NYC would need 15K-20K cases in in the queoe - https://gothamist.com/news/coronavirus-statistics-tracking-epidemic-new-york

Reasons:
1. With the phase 1 reopening underway in June. a new spike should start in July sometime. 
2. Just the shear population density of 9 Million makes any spike result in 1,000 cases easily. 
3. With no law requiring social distancing or face masks it's easy to see how the spike will come this summer. It's when not if.
2nd wave -- people ignoring safety with reopening.

Based on estimates that 20% of NYC residents have been infected I don't expect a second wave there and think they have something close enough to herd immunity to prevent any large outbreaks from happening there again.

Now we are back at March levels, took about a month to rise to 1000 hospitalisations In order to reach 1000 again, we need 3rd/4th/5th order infections for there to be critical mass to fill hospitals again.  Given recent activity and protests, this should take 2 to 3 months depending on (a) speed of spread (b) shielding of vulnerable people (c) movement of people around the city https://www1.nyc.gov/site/doh/covid/covid-19-data.page
NYC already had a burn through
It will take a massive second wave.    Cuomo will move faster if indicators point to a second wave.

If there is a second wave of this scale in cities like New York then we'll all have much much bigger problems to worry about than our Brier scores. (Also I believe that governments currently have all the tools available to them that are necessary to prevent this outcome. Of course, they had them in January and February, but they were stupid and hopefully learned a lesson, and they have more tools now.)
Updating: Numbers are continuing to drop.  Accounting for the possibility of an upswing due to protests.
covid on wane, any return smaller, and not before winter.

Resource here: https://www1.nyc.gov/site/doh/covid/covid-19-data.page
Trying to figure out what effect the protests will have. In a month we should know.
The biggest threat is the opening of schools which doesn't happen in New York until September. It is unlikely we will see that dramatic a spike in the first few weeks the semester.

Based on available data and trends, and considering the extreme hit they took with COVID already, I think people there will attempt preventative measures longer and more widely throughout the population there.  Once things pick up again in the fall with cooler weather and flu season, and after extended periods of social distancing fatigue, more cases will emerge leading to more hospitalizations.

Reason:
1. Re-Opening on June 8 of Phase 1 
2. The onset of warmer summer weather.
3. As second wave is expected by all
4.The virus incubation period is about 2 weeks.
5. That would put the next peak about end of July into Aug at the earliest.
And into Sep on the outside. And therefore the 50-50 split in my prediction between July-Aug.

Hospitalizations were at 20 today. New York is opening back up but will be quickest to react. Couple that with New York’s high reported antibodies (>25%) and people knowing how to social distance, I’m assuming New York’s R0 will stay low, thus keeping New York low through the summer.  Leaving small percent chance in August and September to reflect that there’s some chance of a summer spike as people grow weary of social distancing.
Virus has slow down in Asia, then in Europe. Something is restarting in China since few days. Just add 3 months.

current Hospitalization rate is less than 100 day and has been for at least a week. Although mostly unreliable, case numbers also seem to be declining. The city has been cautious to open. Cuomo has shown strong leadership. I do believe gov will be quick to lock down if necessary.  People and businesses are getting smarter about how to adapt, which lowers the probably of another outbreak.  a ten fold increase seems like a big deal given all that we know now That said, it took less than 20 days to hit that mark the first time, so I don’t rule it out. I also think people will get lax with quarantine protocols and so the longer this drags on, the more likely we are to hit prior hospitalization rates. We may see it, but given the lag between infection and hospitalization it still seems unlikely to happen before 10/1.

NY total numbers are going down, NY hospitals are better at recognizing who probably needs hospitalization than they were in the beginning, and doctors are better at treating severe cases.  The protests (in NY) may cause a spike in cases, but the governor will address that aggressively.
Slightly adjusting to not before 1 October.
At present speed and rate, this does not appear likely to occur in the summer.

Warmer weather, and a "once-bitten twice-shy" population and government make it unlikely that any spike will get near the dimensions of the initial horror wave when the virus was clearly spreading widely through the community before anyone was aware of it.

Very low chance due to the following 
Favourable weather
Partial herd immunity
Political will.   They were badly burned and will take steps to avoid being burnt again
Protests and reopening will cause another outbreak in cases and hospitalization

Restrictions being lifted, current events bringing people into close proximity, and panic fatigue may lead to a quick uptick in hospitalizations for confirmed cases (low 300’s today with many restrictions lifted by 6/22). Taking reported incubation period and assuming initial spread around the end of this month leads me to believe a strong possibility of 700+ new hospitalizations by early to mid July.

Asymptomatic college students will be dispersing NYC to other various areas.  Their departure outweighs the arrival of other students who will be monitored by their colleges.  What will cause the influx of cases will be people relaxing the rules.

Lots of pressure to keep social distancing or threatening to take steps back is a concern and being expressed emotionally with micro gestures by Cuomo. A lot of people have left the city, to the Hamptons, and if NYC takes a step back the wealthy will stay away and stay online. Camps are closed. The government response apparatus will be in a reactive mode, and hospitalization numbers reflect actions taken about two weeks earlier. A substantial increase in hospitalizations will lead the response to curtain openings again.
IHME  projections for the nation, plus historical

Data currently for NYC are trending downwards significantly, and while we don't know much about the it, the nCoV-19 virus  struggles in the heat and does better in the fall, winter, and early spring.  We are currently seeing a huge resurgence in the southern hemisphere and should expect that to move northwards once the fall comes.
I would not expect a second wave until the winter and would not expect it to be as severe as the first wave.

In the initial wave, hospitalizations rose from 10-20 to 1000 in two weeks. But the conditions present for that quick of a rise are no longer present and are unlikely to come back close to that level .Human behavior has been changed by the virus and possibly a third of the population likely have anti-body immunity. If another wave starts, it will be slower and there will be more time to react. Still scarred from their experiences and still in the process of opening back up, with summer weather leading to people spending more time outside (which seems to make spread more difficult), it seems very unlikely that a wave big enough to get to 1000 hospitalizations will happen soon. If a major second wave comes, it seems by far most likely in the fall when the weather pushes people inside and people have had time to let their guards down. The virus' spread is relentless though, so earlier waves in the next few months can't be completely ruled out.
People in NYC have seen how bad it can get and will be careful and will heed public health advice if they are encouraged to decrease contacts.
Memorial Day weekend followed by the BLM protest combined with people not wearing facemasks.

The only way NYC hits a peak as high as the first during the summer is if we have overly lax opening of larger indoor spaces (low chance) and have an incredibly hot summer (high chance). It's not just cold that dives people inside and the South / South West may be finding that out now as cases are spiking along with heatwaves. Note that this would still be Wave 1 burning faster and surging higher. Even after Oct. 1, the danger isn't that Covid goes back to the peak (which I think is less than 20% chance...or maybe just hope as a NYCer!) but that Covid + Flu together make it worse than in April.

Because the downward trend so far is about 1000 fewer hospitalizations every 10 days (from 5/30 to 6/7). And New Yorkers have been pretty careful.  So about 14 days from6/7 it should be just below 1000.  That's 7/21.  However, the massive crowding at street protests will probably slow down the decline in numbers.

Cooler weather will lead to more individuals clustering indoors increasing risk of person to person transmission.  There are few documented cases of outdoor transmission of COVID-19.  In as much as summer months enable more outdoor activities, significant infection rates will likely not resume before Fall.

This is a model-based forecast based on the following assumptions - 95% confidence that the true number of infections is between 6 and 14 times greater than the number of cases
- Average of 18 days of contagiousness
- Virus confers immunity in most cases
- Serological testing indicating that approx. 2,000,000 NYC residents have antibodies is accurate
- R0 is not likely to fall below its current level (0.77), not likely to rise above 2, and most likely to sit somewhere around 1.5 after reopening
- Around 25% of cases require hospitalization - and around 2.5% of infections.
NYC will no have another day where 1000 confirmed Covid-19 are hospitalized in a single day. (Gut, intuition, strain data immunity patterns and disease progression...but mainly gut)
Open air living does limit spread of the virus, the Covid-19 virus will start spreading faster as US enters the cooler months of Fall.

lag from reopen for other states is approximately 1-1.5 months, which would put the uptick some time in august. we are already at 535, and when the previous infection rate, it would take about 5 days to reach 1000, but that's unrealistic with a slow reopen and masks. With a very low increase of 1.02x a day it would take 32 days to reach 1000. 1.5 months from June 8th seems like a realistic center for an obvious ramp up, which is late July.

Cases lower than the peak and going down. Protests and reopening may lead to more, so rates may rise.  A relatively small % of cases lead to hospitalization, though. So I think that rate is not likely to be seen until after schools open in the fall.
Cases currently low and declining.  Protesters and reopening possibly exposing more people to virus.  So I think it will exceed 1000 a day at some point.  But it may  take a little while
People will not practice strict social distancing in July and August. This will lead to a resurgence of virus cases in September.
Testing out the tools for the first time.
The initial wave of Covid19 was traumatic. A second surge is unavoidable, but NYC will do well to stem the flow.

Initial wave pre-citywide stay at home orders took a little over a month to reach 1000 hospitalizations. With reopening scheduled for different parts of the city in June, would expect to see a rise in cases over a month to 3 months after, and a corresponding rise in hospitalization rates.

The climb down was about six weeks. It can take two weeks for symptoms to show up. Rules out July 1. They know nursing homes are vulnerable and are taking better precautions (one hopes). If people wear masks and social distance it should slow rise. Observation is a lot of people have become lax and are not taking precautions so only a partial slowing of a rise back up. I estimate 7-8 weeks it will be back to 1,000 or more.
Schools will be the leading indicator, plus 6 weeks
NYC is opening later than the surrounding area and should be able to avoid superspreader events until schools/events open back up
It'll bump back up now that they're reopening, but it'll take a while.

People already itchy to get out after months of quarantine.  NYC reopening.  Summer heat will make that worse and makes people reckless.  BLM protests a reason to go out.  Concentrated population.  All argues for 100+ spike sooner rather than later
Warm weather, use of masks, and social distancing will lead to a slow uptick after Labor Day, but will probably explode in late Fall.

If there is going to be a surge in hospitalizations, it will likely occur after 1) exposure during priests and rioting surrounding George Floyd and the aftermath, 2) people become tired of isolating and their aversion to risk decreases to a point where there are willing to out regardless of restriction, 3) lifting social restrictions could also contribute (although I believe protests and riots will likely be a biggest contributor because people are reacting based on emotion, which can compromise judgment in how they social distances). Regardless, unless protesting grows into a much larger, longer-term moment, I believe this will only create a blip. I choose slightly higher probabilities in Jun-Jul because of these factors, also considering the incubation period. September is low because I believe, based on what I’ve read, that the virus will slows over the summer (partially due to weather, partially do to improved knowledge if how to handle the virus, partially because I don’t expect wide-spread growth of protests, riots, and looting). Finally, I chose a much higher probability increased risk in Q4 because of the possibility of this becoming a seasonal illness or winter bringing in a second major round of infections.
I'll follow the logic offered by @Moulin and raise my bid higher.

The highest number of new hospitalizations for one day was 6 April with 1709. The time period from the first to the last day of above 1000 new hospitalizations was 23 of March to 14 of April. Right now the number of hospitalizations per day is trending downwards and seem to be under 100 per day.[1]
From what I can gather around 20% in New York had antibodies against Covid-19 in the beginning of May which should have gone up a bit. [2, 3] While this will not stop the disease, it should slow the spread. 
I do believe the spread of the corona virus will be slower during summer as other viruses usually work. There is also some preliminary research pointing to this.[4]  
The protests right now might spread the disease faster, but as the protesters are mostly young they won't usually need hospitalization, so it depends to what extent the protesters meet with elderly.   I predict the spread will be slow during summer but will speed up in autumn. If the number of hospitalizations reaches more than 1000 a day it won't happen before October when I think the weather is more favorable to the spread of the virus. 1. https://www1.nyc.gov/site/doh/covid/covid-19-data.page
2. https://www.nytimes.com/2020/04/23/nyregion/coronavirus-antibodies-test-ny.html
3. https://www.amny.com/coronavirus/latest-antibody-study-report-shows-up-to-20-of-nyc-residents-had-covid-19/
4. https://www.health.com/condition/infectious-diseases/coronavirus/does-sunlight-really-kill-covid-19-heres-what-doctors-say
The summer months will see a lot less transmission as people meet more outside. Thanksgiving and Christmas are significant risks with many expected to have a series extended gatherings indoors.
Current social distancing practices coupled with the fact that summer means more time outdoors will keep infections at their current plateau. When cold weather returns, cases will rise again.
State is beginning to reopen, people will go outside and not distance as weather gets warmer.

20% in July possible due to the protests in June based on the spread due to Infected shouting slogans on top of their lungs and contaminating the clothing of the quiet protesters and ultimately inserting the viral load into their homes.
65% in October following the lag in schools and colleges opening in September.  Most super spreading events occur in indoor environments.
We are still at the beginning with this virus.

I live in NYC and I can tell you from personal experience that - in my neighborhood - there is very little social distancing or mask-wearing among younger people. Whether this is because NYC has started phase 1 of re-opening and they are under the impression there is no more risk or just plain apathy, who can say. With Memorial Day weekend, the BLM protests (during which people were wearing masks, at the very least) and re-opening, I predict there is a high probability of a spike in hospitalizations coming very soon.
It’s a fairly even chance across all dates as New York might reinstate some form of lockdown should cases rise quickly.
I think between now and early fall cases in NYC will continue to fall. I believe if it goes over 1000 new hospitalizations for a single daily total it won’t be until mid-October to early November.

The virus already swept through 20% of population in NYC. These 20% within General Population potentially means much higher proportion among most vulnerable / predisposed / easier-to-infect subgroups. So speaking about the rest of genpop (80%), this group is not the same as the first 20% - it will not be as easy to reach and infect these 80%. Plus in addition the these 20%, the virus probably already attempted to infect 5-10% of population but was repelled by their inmate immune system and pre-existing cross-immunity. Summer months will only improve these defense mechanisms temporarily. So in total we might be speaking about 30%+ of population being excluded from any further virus spread. Or ~40%+ of population to exclude if we speak about the effective base (taking into account easiness to reach and to infect those people who can fuel new infections & hospitalization). But 30-40% exclusion is a noticeable blow into how quickly the virus can spread. If the mobility of people would remain as low as it was in April-May then I would predict that 1000 of hospitalizations would be reached not earlier than Mid-December or more likely - NEVER.  But a plan for re-opening economy and growth of mobility has unknown yet schedule, pushing this date much earlier. I assume that previous exposure to virus has much higher incidence than confirmed 20% because of the reasons above. If that assumption is true, the effect of lockdown / re-opening would be overestimated.

Antibody studies conducted in NYC around 20 April showed that around 20% of NYC residents were carrying the covid-19 antobodies (where there is no official confirmation that these people will not be re-infected, general virus behavior shows that reinfection should be rare)
https://www.nytimes.com/2020/04/23/nyregion/coronavirus-antibodies-test-ny.html This means that around 1.6 million to 1.7 million residents in NYC would have had the virus (vs the official count of 200k). So we cant rely on the daily positive counts to get any data (it is purely a function of the no of tests done). And a LARGE number of cases are asymptomatic.  Considering that the virus would have been in NYC since Nov 19, we could assume that the current antibody carrying rate of NYC residents might be in the 25% range (this is aggressive and the shutdown would have decreased the spread).  The spread of the virus in a community with 0% - 5% antibody carriers would be very different from a community with 20% - 25% antibody carriers. Plus there is more physical distancing, preventive measures (use of masks) and awareness now (especially in a place like NYC).  I believe that the battleground has shifted from NYC (after extracting a terrible toll). The battle is now in other states (AZ, CA, TX) and cities and we should not be seeing a 1,000 plus hospitalization rate soon (or at least before 1st October) in NYC due to covid-19.

Some chance that cases will increase as the state begins to open up but enforced social distancing and poor conditions for viral transmission will keep levels low through the summer.  Rt in NY is currently 0.77. A steady drop in cases will create a false sense of security and cases will begin to increase in September after schools reopen.

Looking quickly at the date, it takes about 4k or more people testing positive to get 1k or more hospitalizations [1]. With the increase in testing rates right now, it seems like anyone with symptoms will know more quickly than in March. Additionally, there is a better sense of what social distancing, masks, etc. can do, plus the protocols to take when you are sick. Will keep an eye on this, but I can't see it escalating as quickly as it did in March.  [1] https://www1.nyc.gov/site/doh/covid/covid-19-data.page
additional loosening of restrictions and large group events
Memorial day holiday crowds and BLM protest will likely result in an increase in confirmed confirmed cases of more than 1,000 on a day before July 1
I have been following this topic closely and have strong conviction regarding when the situation will escalate.
based on protests and quarantine fatigue

It's been two months exactly since there were 1000 hospitalizations in NYC. A lot has been learned and hopefully incorporated into daily practices. My assumption is that level will not again be reached this summer. I've peanut buttered the remainder probabilities with a place holder as I've been wrong, twice before. :-)

Memorial day began 22 and many folks went outside -the weather was good and some people went outside of the state. We are now week three and just seeing the initial pop from memorial day, which still needs another 2 weeks to really get momentum, which brings it to 29 June. Then we have protests which began and escalated quickly with many not wearing masks. But masks are protection, if you also do the rest, wash hands, etc. This will bring another pop ont he 29 June. Trends show it goes down then does the reversal almost doubling the lowest bar. March 15th was when NYC hit over a 1K, and March 23 1K hospitalizations. This disease scaled faster than than it takes to flatten. 
Data: https://www1.nyc.gov/site/doh/covid/covid-19-data.page
https://www.worldometers.info/coronavirus/usa/new-york/
https://www.syracuse.com/coronavirus-ny/

Despite the city slowly opening, and widespread protest activity, cases are still declining. # of people tested has not significantly declined, however % of people positive has. This would point to positive trends in distancing and mask-wearing activity, for now. Given NYC's ability to go from a virus epicenter to less than 100 new cases a day in a relatively short amount of time, with a high population density, the chances of them going to > 1000 hospitalizations in a day would required something on the order of > 4k new cases in a day, based on prior data. That doesn't look like it's going to happen anytime soon.

NYC residents were so terribly affected that they are going to be more conservative in discarding the extreme measures of this spring. In addition, NY state has a very reasonable and intelligent governor who has provided leadership through this crisis.

Primary thinking is that it is unlikely that transmission will see levels on par w/ initial outbreak, given the knowledge/experience/protocols now in place to prevent another surge on that scale. I would feel less confident about this if we were talking about a different municipality, but New York State and New York City have shown a willingness to take broad and decisive action, and I suspect they would be quick to do so well before hospitalizations reached the rate described above. I do believe that CASES will likely surge within this timeframe, to levels at or above previous peak, but I think that will be largely due to increased testing, and perhaps some increase in transmission, but I'm bearish on it translating to a level of acute cases requiring hospitalization above the subject threshold.

Despite the crowded protests, most people are wearing masks. Testing is available to everyone as of this week and there's contact tracing in place. A good portion of the population has built antibodies, and many of us lost a loved one, got infected ourselves or know someone who died from it which should make us more cautious. So I wouldn't expect the same scenario as late March, early April. 
Daily averages this week are ~30.
